question: Sir. Sir, may I have a ticket to Montreal please? I need a ticket to Montreal. Yes, sir. Please.
answer: Dan Soulsby.

question: Martin. Nice to meet you.
answer: Where you heading to?

question: Away from here. Pisswater.
answer: At least it's cold pisswater. Here's to getting away. They CLINK CANS. The Driver enters the bus. Unlocks the airbrakes. Puts the bus in reverse, gives it gas. BOOM! The ENGINE throws a rod. Horrible GRINDING. Smoke wafts into the windows. The Driver KILLS the ENGINE. Silence. Martin and Dan trade looks. That was bad. It's gonna take all day to get another bus here. Martin sighs, looks out the window.

question: You have a license?
answer: Had one. They took it away.

question: I got one. Let's go.
answer: See that? They're all fake.

question: You take a hockey puck in the face?
answer: A fist. My stepdad socked me. I flew across the room and dented the sheetrock in the kitchen. My mom saw everything and still took his side.

question: You got cracked good.
answer: I hate that guy. Two hundred pounds of worthless grease.

question: Why'd he hit you?
answer: I wrecked his sixty-five Mustang and his boat in the same week. His babies. I totaled them.

question: I would have popped you too.
answer: It was worth it. But I didn't deserve the tour in hell. Dan rubs his close-cropped hair. Don't ever go to military school if you can help it. It sucks. I jumped the wall two days ago.

question: You going back?
answer: I'm done with that racket. I'm going to Seattle and playing music. Martin tries the guitar, he's not that good.

question: I know some chords.
answer: Think you can learn drums? I'm the next Billy Squire. Krokus will be opening for me one day. POW! The CAR HITS a BOTTLE. A front tire deflates. Martin guides the crippled vehicle to the curb. Shit. Dan hauls the spare from the trunk. Sets the jack under the bumper. A PICKUP TRUCK approaches. Still a mile away. Martin watches Dan lean in the trunk for the tire iron. The pickup gets closer, a big one. Heavy with bags of animal feed. Speeding. Martin looking at Dan's back. Martin shoves Dan hard, into the highway. In front of:

question: Hi. Look, I'm not ready to talk to you guys yet. I need a little more time here. Reynaud and Laval trade looks, walk toward two UNIFORMS guarding the site. Would you mind trading one liners somewhere else? I need to hear the natural sounds. I appreciate it. The policemen have gathered in a chummy knot. Laval gestures for them to walk down the road. Don't shoot, I'm on your team. Reynaud holsters his gun. The men relax. Grace takes Inspector Laval aside. Call who you have to call. I found his head. Laval REACTS.
answer: I can't tell you how excited we are to have you here.

question: You only have one victim. Usually there's two or three by the time I get called in.
answer: This case made page one of the Globe. The tabloids say there is a headhunter on the loose. The Mayor wants closure. That's his vacation house they were building. I get calls from supervisors I didn't know I had.

question: You clear the Mayor?
answer: We cleared the Mayor. He read the article on you in Newsweek and insisted we fly you up. The papers say two campers had a drunken fight and the loser lost his head.

question: What do you think?
answer: I don't solve crimes anymore, I balance budgets.

question: This was not a heat of the moment killing. And the victim was buried complete with head. The grave was five-foot ten. The victim's height. With square corners. Dug with a shovel the killer had the foresight to bring.
answer: Thirty-five detectives searched the area Saturday. My investigators think you're a witch.

question: I've been called worse. The Medical Examiner finds two small holes in the skull, waves the PHOTOGRAPHER over.
answer: Jeez. Look at that, looks like he got ice-picked. She simulates fangs with her hands, they match marks on the skull.

question: Bingo. That's your murder weapon.
answer: It might be trash a camper left.

question: No. Look at it, braided parachute cord, two pieces of broom stick. You approach the victim from behind, loop it around his head and hold on for all your might. The more the victim struggles, the quicker he passes out. And now you have convenient handles to drag around two hundred pounds of dead kayaker.
answer: That is a theory.

question: That's exactly what it is. A theory. That evidence supports. When the suspect is in custody you can ask him yourself what happened and you won't need me. Inspector. Laval bristles, he crosses to check his cell messages. Gillet looks at Grace, at the cord. Turns to her quietly.
answer: Laval and Reynaud are my stars. Very smart, very persistent investigators. On the street; they're magnificent.

question: I can see that Director. You're lucky to have them. A beat. Go ahead, Director, say what you have to say.
answer: You're the expert. If you have any suggestions on how to proceed...

question: Sure. A forensic anthropologist can draw the victim's face based on the skull. I know someone at Quantico who can do it by tomorrow.
answer: We have people.

question: Call 'em. Then show the results to everybody around who was selling outdoor goods two years ago. You have his initials; MRC, inside the wetsuit. The long hair is distinctive, someone may recognize him. It's a semi-long shot.
answer: No, that's bread and butter detective work. Thank you. We should get upstairs. They cross to the exit. Director Gillet barks orders in FRENCH at his two-star Inspectors.

question: Why, after two years, has nobody reported him missing?
answer: He wasn't missed. He had no family, or moved often. He had the musculature of a serious outdoorsman. He spent a lot of time in his kayak.

question: The big question is who killed him.
answer: Always is, sir. I can give you a rough profile; white male, thirty to thirty-four. Has some college but no degree. Neat in appearance. At least six feet tall. Very intelligent. Charming when necessary. He uses murder as a tool, probably in furtherance of a criminal endeavor. He's killed before and will again unless caught. Laval and Reynaud write furiously. Gillet is impressed. As are the Councilmen.

question: We really appreciate the FBI sending you. When can we expect your report?
answer: A couple days, sir.

question: A couple days, sir.
answer: Say hello to a dead man. INSERT SKETCH

question: Shame. Good-looking guy.
answer: This is more than we had. Thank you. Laval has declared peace. Grace smiles. Reynaud still keeps his distance.

question: Vanderholt?
answer: We named the victim; Curtis Kohler. The forensic dentist just verified the ID.

question: With a C?
answer: No. K-O-H-L-E-R. The initials are for the Montreal River Company. Kohler worked there as a guide three years ago. The owner remembers him because he stole the wetsuit.

question: Can you do a full records search? Criminal, credit, commercial history. Transcripts. Everything.
answer: Yes, of course.

question: Let's go down the street. Very good food. We are inviting you. Please. Grace grabs her jacket and an armful of reports.
answer: Mr. Kohler has been dead two years. No doubt about that. Right?

question: Very solid time of death. Two years ago.
answer: So before he died he got his paychecks, paid his taxes. Patronized sporting goods stores. And had long spending gaps where he was enjoying the great outdoors. That pattern continues a year after his death. He gets some paychecks. Rents an apartment. Buys a three thousand dollar kayak. Pays his taxes. Dead and buried and still paying his taxes. Then everything stops. Last Visa charge was to Travelocity for a plane ticket to Mexico city.

question: Dead men don't pay their bills. It's identity theft.
answer: This isn't someone renting limos and fancy dinners on someone else's credit. Lifestyle and habits don't change.

question: Computer error?
answer: Too many independent systems.

question: We work organized crime sometimes, maybe a hit man wanted to lay low. He assumed the life of a civilian until things cooled off.
answer: You really think a gangster is going to break his stride and become a long hair groovy river guide? Inspector, this guy's whole life has been stolen. Someone killed him and became him. Down to profession and taste in clothing. Laval and Reynaud trade looks.

question: You are a heavy sleeper.
answer: You're everywhere. What's up, Laval?

question: A man was killed tonight. Attacked from behind. Asphyxiated with a nylon cord with handles. And there's a witness. Or a suspect. We're not sure yet. We should go. That's him. He says he saw the killer. Reynaud SLAPS the cop car, it quickly drives away. Grace and Laval arrive at a BODY dressed in sweats. A gym bag nearby. A pair of UNIFORMS stand guard as a CRIMINALIST processes the body. Thirty-ish, healthy, his generic looks marred by bulging, bruised eyes. Face bruised. Meet Mr. Todd Ford. Grace squats by the body. CLICKS on her Mag-Lite and inspects the victim. Bruises on his neck.
answer: He's still warm. Want to get those? The Criminalist takes a lint roller, collects the hairs. Where is it?

question: There. Under his car. Grace shines her light under a car. A garrote is there, made of broomsticks and knotted nylon cord.
answer: Holy shit. Has Le Directeur been notified?

question: I walk out of the gym. Walk to my car. I'm unlocking it and I hear a scuffle, a fight. Over by this car I see this guy getting choked from behind and I shouted.
answer: What did you shout?

question: 'Stop.' I ran towards them. Then the person doing the choking lets go and pointed a gun at me and ran. I'm so stupid. I could of been shot. I called the police gave him CPR until the paramedics came.
answer: You touched him?

question: Of course. I was giving him CPR.
answer: You removed the Garrote?

question: The thing around his neck? Yes. I took it off, it was choking him.
answer: Did you see where the attacker went?

question: Away from me.
answer: What kind of gun did he have?

question: The kind that puts really big holes in people.
answer: Was it black? Was it silver?

question: Black.
answer: Okay, see? I am getting information. He had a large black handgun.

question: Listen to me. I can draw a picture of his face. I saw him.
answer: You want to draw a picture?

question: A sketch. I can sketch him. I'm very good.
answer: How could you see his face in the dark? A beat. Costa realizing he is under suspicion. He leans forward, looks Inspector Laval in the eye.

question: Inspector. I need a moment with you. Laval exits the room, shutting the door behind them. A ROOKIE hands Director Gillet a cup of coffee and a new dress shirt wrapped in plastic.
answer: I was getting into his mind.

question: I have a shortcut. Can you get any of his school transcripts?
answer: Sure. It's all on-line. Grace takes an evidence bag containing the garrote from the latest crime scene. She drops it in her computer bag. Grabs a case file.

question: Call the Winnipeg Police and have them fax or e-mail his driver's license photo. Grace crosses, opens the door, enters.
answer: I hope you guys are playing bad cop smart cop.

question: Sorry. I'm the dumb one. Agent Vanderholt. Call me Grace. They shake. She slides typing paper and a pencil over to Costa.
answer: Thank you. He had these real intense eyes.

question: Hold on. Before you do that, I need some personal information from you. Can you write down the name of the elementary school you attended? And your elementary school teachers, as many as you can remember. Costa looking at Grace a beat.
answer: Are you kidding me? Lady, I saw someone get killed tonight and you're asking me about grade school?

question: I apologize, I know it's random, but it's the best way you can help me.
answer: I don't remember any of that.

question: Please, Mr. Costa. You'd be surprised.
answer: I attended two. Holy Trinity and Mother of Good Counsel. I remember Sister Bernard. And. I don't know, Father Jeffrey. Mr. Johansen. Oh, and Mrs. Sebastien, she had a glass eye.

question: May I? She takes the list of names. She tips over her briefcase with her foot, the evidence bag spills out. Costa glances at the garrote, REACTS.
answer: Omigod. That's it, isn't it?

question: That's what?
answer: The thing around his neck. Costa looking at Grace, realizes it's a mind game. I told the other guy, I'll tell you. I did not do this. Grace. I saw who did this and I can show you what he looks like and you can go catch him. Costa is unambiguously sincere. Grace's attitude softens a bit. She tucks the garrote back in her bag.

question: Go ahead and draw the face of the man you saw. Costa draws a simple smiley face. He shows her. We'll get an artist to help you.
answer: I can draw him, thank you. Grace crosses to the door. Costa begins drawing in earnest.

question: You left a file in there.
answer: I know. See if he tries to peek in it. The real killer couldn't resist. He'll want to know what we know. Laval watches Costa. Can you remember any of your grade school teachers? He remembered three. A Rookie crosses with a photo, hands it to Laval.

question: Here's his provincial driver's license photo. He's checking out. Laval shows Grace the photo. It is definitely Costa. A beat.
answer: Have a nurse take a DNA sample. Just to make sure his DNA isn't in the victim's car or anything weird.

question: Fell out of his T-shirt when I removed the clothing. It doesn't fit the victim.
answer: WVSS. 1995. What's that?

question: West Vancouver Secondary School Class of '95.
answer: CWE? Whose initials? Not the victim's.

question: No. I called the school and had someone find them in a yearbook. Here's the original owner's name. But it could have been through a dozen pawn shops since then. He hands her a piece of paper. Grace has a big smile.
answer: Doctor, can I take you back to Quantico with me?

question: Inspector Reynaud. Can we swing by the crime scene before we head back? Inspector. Laval startles. C'mere a second, please. They cross to the victim's car. Borrow your keys? Stand there like you're going to choke me. Grace pantomimes unlocking the door, drops the keys and reaches for her throat. Keys drop straight down, how'd they end up over there under that car?
answer: They were kicked. During the struggle.

question: Okay. Kick them as hard as you can that way. Laval looks at her, kicks his keys. Not even halfway. I had this case. This young hundred-pound woman was abducted from a parking lot. She kicked off a mirror, broke a window, dented her door. She struggled. This guy? Nothing.
answer: Everything you are saying, you are saying one thing, do we trust Costa?

question: Good question. Do we trust Costa? An unmarked car pulls up. Reynaud drives.
answer: Get in. I found a current address here in Montreal. Reynaud leans on the HORN, aggressively maneuvering through traffic.

question: You guys have an extra weapon? I didn't want to cross the border armed.
answer: The glove box. Grace opens it and finds a compact Glock. She checks it, shoves it into her pocket. Reynaud swerves into the wrong lane. Stops cold in front of an apartment building. And gets out. Great driving. A mere two blocks away from the crime scene. Laval gets out. Then Grace.

question: I smell smoke. Back where I'm from anyone can kick a door if there's a fire. It's the 'citizen's arrest' of search warrants. Then Clear. Grace turns off the burner. She crosses to a window, whips aside the curtains, and opens it. Coughing. Ugh. Got a lung full. Looks like this guy ran out in the middle of breakfast. Laval has entered, he stares out the window. Grace looks out the window, REACTS.
answer: We should get out of here. Don't touch anything. They back out of there.

question: Resembles the man Costa sketched. Have you released him? You don't want your star witness steaming in a holding cell.
answer: He went home twenty minutes ago. Agent Grace, where do you think Monsieur Edwards is?

question: I bet Monsieur Edwards is in a deep grave with square corners like Messieurs Kohler and Ford. Which looks like all the victims. Maybe he's subconsciously killing himself. Grace finds a guitar case. Opens it. It's a mobile office; it has postage stamps. Postcards. Assorted stationery, different address labels. Neat, organized. Holiday cards. A CD titled
answer: We'll take that with us. Put a number and seal on that case. Reynaud SNAPS pictures of the guitar case. Grace is absorbing everything this little apartment can tell her. Bonding with the space. She smells a pillow. Thinking.

question: Ever see a Hermit crab?
answer: No.

question: It's a crab that lives in the shells of dead sea snails.
answer: Yes, yes. They have one big claw and curl up tight. Laval takes a long, sharpened screwdriver from his jacket. Begins prying off a door molding. Grace sits at the kitchen table.

question: They're working really hard.
answer: I know.

question: Someone died last night because the asshole we're after isn't in custody. It's happened to me before and I'm sure it will happen again. It's a pretty miserable feeling.
answer: I haven't felt it in a long time. Dinner?

question: I doubt it. He's been so meticulous and effective in the past, I bet he's never needed one. We can assume he has all sorts of fake IDs and passports. Disguises. But that's not enough for him, he has to be someone else. He gets off impersonating people. And he knows his current persona is compromised. Laval and Reynaud have stopped eating, are looking at her. What?
answer: You're always thinking. Save something for tomorrow. We have three boxes of evidence to go through.

question: Pretty cavalier attitude for a man who just got his ass chewed by his boss.
answer: My papa dropped dead of a heart attack in front of a drill press at work. Not me. Grace understands. Laval CLINKS her beer, Reynaud too.

question: Mr. Costa.
answer: You caught me.

question: Not yet. Grace looks over the art.
answer: Toussant Jean Bernard. I met him in Haiti last year. Very troubled life. Outlived all his children. And he had ten. He lost his wife to cancer and went blind. Passed away last year.

question: Overpriced folk art. Is it the work of a soul that has suffered? Sure. Are his explorations as an artist groundbreaking? No.
answer: Ouch. And I was going to send you two and charge them to your Amex.

question: I couldn't afford it. Costa is looking at her, looking through her.
answer: What about Daddy's Amex? I've sold quite a bit of art to poor little rich girls like you.

question: Excuse me.
answer: Try the wine.

question: I'm partial to beer. And I don't have long. I came by to thank you for your help. And I apologize if you were detained. You did the right thing. Trying to save him.
answer: Why, thank you. Agent Vanderholt. I'm having a show Friday. You should come by and meet some good people.

question: Who knows. Where'd you learn CPR?
answer: Medical school. Before I dropped out. I had a moment of clarity

question: Some journey.
answer: It's taken me all over the world.

question: About Monday again, did you see Mr. Ford fighting back?
answer: At first I thought I was interrupting something, you know?

question: No, I don't.
answer: I thought they were hugging. Then the gun came out when he saw me.

question: I guess that's it. Thanks. Grace hands him a card. If you remember any details or need anything. Anything related to the case, please call me.
answer: Okay. Think about Friday. Please, Grace? Grace will; she exits.

question: Morning. Can you run this name? She got twenty hang-up calls from Edward's phone. The Young Detective takes a Post-It from Grace and crosses. What happened to that beautiful thumbprint on the orange juice glass, you get an ID?
answer: No hits. He's never been fingerprinted.

question: Shit. Any activity on Edward's accounts?
answer: Nothing. I think he became Edwards a year ago. He was a software engineer. Did everything by the internet, he never met anyone face to face. Grace trades Reynaud for the front page.

question: Why a year ago.
answer: Edwards went on a river trip. Kohler was a guide. Grace REACTS. Laval tosses her some papers. Those are E-mails between Kohler and Edwards discussing the trip one year ago.

question: You connected Edwards and Kohler? Somebody was working all night.
answer: I couldn't sleep.

question: Our suspect kills Kohler on the river, lives his life a year, kills Edwards and assumes his ID for a year. Then he stalks Ford, kills him but is interrupted by Costa. Think he's pissed at Costa?
answer: Of course. The Young Detective returns with a report, hands it to Grace.

question: She must have sounded like a total fruitcake.
answer: This is it. Grace watching Laval. He looks pretty rough this morning.

question: Let me go and be non-threatening.
answer: Hi, please come in. Thank you for coming. I'm glad they finally sent someone, those hang-up calls have me terrified. They started right after I saw him. I looked him directly in the eye. There was a moment of mutual recognition.

question: Do you think it's Martin calling and hanging up?
answer: It couldn't sound crazier, but who else?

question: Were you ever asked to identify his body?
answer: The body? Yes, they showed me some remains that had been hit by a pickup truck. The upper body was crushed. There was no face. I got physically ill. Mrs. Asher studies Grace. You're not Canadian, are you?

question: No. I'm with the FBI. Grace shows her creds.
answer: There was three. About two weeks ago. I began turning off my telephone when I go to bed.

question: You have some very nice things, Mrs. Asher.
answer: Thank you. Some of them have been in my family for several generations. Please call me Rebecca. Grace looking at pictures on the wall of a good-looking, athletic kid. They stop at age fourteen.

question: Is that Martin?
answer: No. That's Reese. Martin's older brother. He drowned in a terrible accident. Grace notes a photo of a smiling young REESE receiving a long distance swimming trophy.

question: I'm so sorry, Rebecca. How did he drown?
answer: The San Michel River. Martin fell out of their raft and Reese jumped in to save him. There was a lot of snowmelt that year. Martin reached the bank. Reese didn't. It was their fourteenth birthday.

question: Their fourteenth birthday?
answer: They were twins. Identical twins.

question: You said Reese was older.
answer: By three minutes. They were very different boys.

question: To lose one son so young, then to lose the other two years later; to think you've lost him. That must have been devastating. Mrs. Asher lights a cigarette. Crosses to the window, so poised, so tragic. Grace studies her with a critical eye.
answer: Reese was very charismatic and outgoing. Martin was introverted. He never thrived like Reese. He was a very disturbed young man. Reese was Martin's world. Martin never recovered his equilibrium after we lost him. He changed. Martin began to intimidate me. He could be very menacing. He began imitating Reese at school and that lead to fights with other students. At sixteen he stole some jewelry that was very precious to me and ran away. A few days later the Thunder Bay police called and said my son had been killed changing a tire.

question: The police want you to sign this so they can exhume the body in Martin's grave and verify identity.
answer: I'll sign it. I already know somebody else's son is in that casket. The PHONE RINGS. Excuse me. Mrs. Asher crosses to the kitchen and answers. Grace looking around, takes a look down a hallway. LAUGHTER O.S. as Mrs. Asher chats with a friend. The bathroom is there. Grace startles. Mrs. Asher is right behind her.

question: I know. I was snooping. Grace closes the door. Mrs. Asher escorts Grace away, past the boys' room.
answer: My friends call it the shrine. It can be difficult to let go.

question: I know. A beat.
answer: He's killing people, isn't he? Grace nods

question: That doesn't surprise you?
answer: No. It doesn't.

question: She signed. Start digging.
answer: Hmm. Could be worse after getting run over by a pickup and twenty years in the ground. Bodies get mixed up all the time. Police found the wallet, called the mother and nothing was cross- checked. This was his head. Medical Examiner pulls a plastic bag from the coffin. Slices it open, revealing skull fragments and teeth. Passes them off to an ASSISTANT. Get that to Doctor Shivani and make sure someone signs for it. She'll rebuild his jaw line and check it against Martin Asher's dental X-rays.

question: How soon, sir?
answer: This is a priority case, this afternoon maybe.

question: Vanderholt.
answer: Am I interrupting something?

question: Yes. What?
answer: The X-rays don't match.

question: Find the real Martin Asher. He's your killer. You better get his mother someplace safe. How'd she finagle a room there?
answer: She's a very slick woman.

question: She didn't have one picture of Martin. Not one. Even cut him out of the old yearbooks. And she had a basement door like a vault. She's hiding something. In the basement of her house. What is it, ten minutes away from here? Her house. A beat. Laval looks at Grace, decides he can trust her.
answer: If she's under our protection and something happens to her house, her belongings, the department could be liable. There could be a lawsuit.

question: You're right. We should make sure her front door is locked. Laval makes a U-turn.
answer: I'll stay outside. Kill him if he's in there.

question: Yeah, I'll get 'em. Grace enters with a flashlight and a pistol. She cautiously clears each room until she is sure she is alone. Grace crosses to the hallway. The little dog is there. GROWLING. Grace tosses it a hamburger patty. Let's be friends. The dog happily attacks its treat as Grace opens the deadbolts on the door the little dog was guarding. I think I just shaved ten years off my life.
answer: Ah, you do feel fear.

question: Yes. Rabies scares me. Only rabies. Nothing else. Her CELL RINGS. Vanderholt.
answer: Grace. Someone broke into my office. Minutes ago.

question: At the art gallery?
answer: Yes. My office here.

question: Are they still there?
answer: No.

question: Did you call the police?
answer: You told me to call you if anything happened.

question: We'll be right there. I'm sending a car. Don't touch anything.
answer: I do all my calls to Europe and shipping stuff at night. My address book was on the screen when I went out for coffee. I came back and this was on the screen.

question: How long were you gone?
answer: Ten minutes. Maybe. When I returned, that was on the screen. Is this about the strangling? Is that guy after me?

question: I must of walked right past him.
answer: Mr. Costa, is that the man you saw kill Mr. Ford in the parking lot?

question: Yes. That's him. That is the man I saw murder Todd Ford in the parking lot outside my gym. No doubt. Now will you go catch him, please?
answer: Thank you. I just needed you to say it.

question: Who is this guy? He's like a Ninja. Sneaking into my office. How dangerous is he? Does he want to kill me?
answer: John, no harm will come to you. Listen to me. No harm will come to you. I promise. Anyone who wants to hurt you will have to get through these two for starters.

question: Costa fits Asher's choice of victims. Travels the World looking for art. Single. No kids or anything. Asher's here somewhere. Watching. With all the patience in the world.
answer: I wish I had his patience. He should be a cop. His mother should be punished. Like the owner of pit bulls that attack kids.

question: You got kids?
answer: Three.

question: Don't keep them in a cage.
answer: What? I have a life. I can't play superhero for you. I don't handle stress very well. I have an art show to open tomorrow and I don't know what I'm putting on the walls yet.

question: I know you have a life. So did the people who have lost theirs. Someone else might die if you do not help us. Every time someone dies it affects forty, fifty lives. Costa looks at her, arms on his hips.
answer: Grace, I've been cooperating. I even drew you a picture. You can't put your responsibility on me. You have a badge, not me.

question: If somebody else dies, and you know you could have done more to stop it, you're going to feel like shit for a very long time, Mr. Costa. A beat. That resonates with Costa.
answer: I want to help you guys but I don't have time to hang out and listen to bad techno.

question: It's okay to be scared.
answer: Scared? I'm off-the-charts terrified. There's a pissed-off serial killer after me. I mean, what did I do to him?

question: You saw him and that's enough. Don't stop living your life. You'll be protected by armed officers twenty-four seven.
answer: Until he's caught?

question: I can't promise you that. Costa is torn, Grace empathizes with him.
answer: I have a lot of work to do.

question: I'm sure Soulsby's death was a homicide, Asher saw the opportunity and took it. He became Soulsby and bummed around Seattle for a couple years.
answer: Why is Asher after Costa? Why isn't he in Mexico getting a new face?

question: Costa saw him. Costa caught him in the act, caught him being Martin Asher. Seen first by his mother, then by Costa. For the first time he's failed at taking a life, and since we found the apartment, he can't be Edwards. To be seen, to be recognized, is a horrifying thing to Asher. He has no identity and wants it that way.
answer: Where is the real Mr. Edwards?

question: Likely dead and buried south of the border somewhere. South of the American border somewhere. Visa records put Asher, using Kohler's ID and Edwards at a Mexican surf resort. Edwards' last charge was sixteen hundred dollars at a 'no questions asked' facelift clinic in Guadalajara. Director Gillet taps out his pipe. Looks at a new, more detailed portrait of Asher.
answer: Have you contacted the clinic?

question: Keep's the collection agencies off the trail. How do we flush Mr. Asher?
answer: He's focused on Costa. Who fits the profile of Asher's victims. He went on Costa's computer and E- mailed copies of Costa's files to an E-mail account in Denmark. Constant threat of discovery, Asher will become more disorganized. Laval and Reynaud agree.

question: Okay. My office will arrange a press conference. I will tell a room full of correspondents we have a suspect who is dead and murder victims who are alive. And I'll sound like a madman.
answer: It does sound crazy. That's what the press likes, sir.

question: They're protecting the art. Go ahead and hang those. Be very careful.
answer: Security is going to be very solid tonight. She waves him out of earshot of the Carpenters. Their faces are close. Grace gets butterflies.

question: Is he going to show up tonight? What do I do, offer him a drink?
answer: He won't show. But we want to be here in case he does. Four plainclothes officers will form a perimeter watching the four corners.

question: A perimeter, excellent.
answer: Yes. And four plainclothes officers will be in here. Mingling.

question: Mingling? I don't need four bruisers crashing through my clientele.
answer: The officers will be very discreet. We won't interfere with your thing.

question: With my thing. Will you be mingling?
answer: Sure. If you feel safer.

question: Thanks.
answer: You look a little anxious.

question: This isn't me.
answer: It's all you. Grace gives Costa a look. She sips her drink, nods at the painting.

question: I'm trying to get into the show, but I mean. What is this? It looks like somebody napalmed the Garden of Eden.
answer: Mangos. Ripe mangos hanging on a branch. Now she sees it.

question: Oh. Okay. Why the borders? Almost every painting has one. Was he in prison or something? Costa REACTS, impressed by Grace.
answer: Most people don't notice. This is from his prison series. He could see a mango grove through his cell window. He made some of the pigments himself. From flowers. From his own blood.

question: What was his crime?
answer: He attacked his neighbor with a machete. There was a woman involved.

question: Always is. Grace sips her drink, letting herself relax. She enjoys Costa's company. He had a lot of lovers, didn't he?
answer: Dozens. He was a consumer of life's pleasures.

question: Now he's dead and you get rich?
answer: His children formed a corporation, I take ten percent. I'm not a buccaneer, Grace. Grace looks at Costa and smiles. What?

question: I don't think I've ever met anyone quite like you.
answer: You're very sensitive for...

question: An FBI agent? The ELEGANT WOMAN spots Costa and crosses. She lays a hand on Costa's shoulder. He turns and they kiss cheeks. Mr. Costa, I would like to discuss an arrangement for the series. The Elegant Woman REACTS.
answer: What are you doing?

question: She's not writing the checks. The Elegant Woman returns with the Older Man. He grabs Costa's hand.
answer: Dick, they're yours. The Older Man smiles, shakes Costa's hand. The Elegant Woman looking at Grace, arms crossed, enjoys her victory. Grace plays along, stalks off, hiding a grin.

question: Don't you miss wax?
answer: You helped me close the biggest sale of the night.

question: What's my cut?
answer: What do you want? Grace smiles coyly.

question: I don't know. Costa looks at Grace for a long beat. Not sure what her game is, or if he wants to play.
answer: Let me know when you do. Excuse me. Costa walks away. Grace REACTS; she didn't want that.

question: Let me know when you do. Excuse me. Costa walks away. Grace REACTS; she didn't want that.
answer: Put your hands on the wall. Asher jams a gun in Costa's back. Costa is very scared. Feel that?

question: Please be cool with that. I don't wanna get hurt.
answer: I should blow your spine out. My face is everywhere. I have to hide in the shadows like a fucking animal because of you.

question: Yessir. I apologize for everything you think I may have done.
answer: We're moved past sorry. You ruined everything. John, soon to be dead, Costa. Asher's eyes flash. WHAM! Asher slams Costa's face into the mirror. Costa's nose bleeds.

question: Need a ride home? Costa looks at her. Despite everything, his face shows he is glad to see Grace.
answer: The night started out great. Everything gelled. Everyone was happy. You helped land a big fish and the feeding frenzy started. Six figure pieces were flying off the wall. He said he was going to blow out my spine. I was thinking surgery. Six months in bed. Exercise pools. Never walking again. Grace looks at him. Costa is worried. He was in my bathroom and none of you could stop him. I need to leave town.

question: That might be a good idea. Until then I'll check under your bed for monsters. Costa looks at her. Grace gives him a warm, open stare.
answer: I would appreciate that very much. Can I profile you? I read your book.

question: Please, don't.
answer: Thirty-something, single white female. Best schools best grades. Discovers adrenaline policing the inner city.

question: John, stop it. Please. Let's shift the conversation from me and my business onto something inbounds.
answer: Okay. Are you going to my funeral when Martin Asher cuts my throat? They both know she's been lowballing the threat. We can tell Grace is truly concerned for Costa's welfare. You let him get away. Grace takes that hard.

question: No excuses. I'm sorry.
answer: I meant you in the general sense. Can you catch him?

question: We got his name. We catch everyone sooner or later.
answer: Sooner, please. Careful. Costa scoots aside a pile of clothing. The newspapers. Cool art, sketches, images all over the walls. Reminiscent of Grace's hotel room. And a very cool view of downtown. Grace taking everything in. Art books, sketch pads. Piled high on the desk. She looks at the ceiling. SEES notes and sketches taped up. Grace laughs to herself. I'm sorry. It's a sty. Must be a profiling mother lode.

question: I'm done profiling you. I got you figured out.
answer: A failed healer, a failed artist. Grace looking at a drawing on the wall. Costa winces, he didn't want her to notice it.

question: Is that how you see yourself?
answer: No. That's you. I did it last night.

question: This is how you see me?
answer: No. It's how I think you see yourself.

question: And how do you see me? Costa licks his lips.
answer: That would be out of bounds. Grace looking at him. Costa looking at her. A staring match. Costa and Grace try not to laugh. They end up giggling. What was that?

question: I don't know. John, games are fun. But head games are dangerous.
answer: Then keep your head out of it. A beat. Grace shrugs, back to business.

question: The Justice minister is going to relocate you to another city until Mr. Asher is in custody.
answer: I don't know what your deal is. One second you're so there, then all I get is the badge.

question: I apologize if you've been getting the wrong signal.
answer: Yeah. Relocate where?

question: Another province. They want you on a flight tomorrow morning.
answer: This monster comes into my life and I have to leave? A UNIFORM SERGEANT enters.

question: Thank you, Sergeant. The Sergeant exits.
answer: This is surreal. What do I pack?

question: What you need. Movers can get the rest.
answer: I need tomorrow morning to finish up my business here.

question: I'll let them know. This is goodbye. Neither of them feels very good about it.
answer: I thought you were going to check under my bed. Grace smiles, plays along, crosses, looks under the bed, stretching for Costa. Driving him nuts.

question: No monsters.
answer: Thank you. Grace holds out her hand. They shake.

question: I probably won't see you again until the trial. If there is a trial.
answer: Goodbye, then. Costa leans across her, braces himself against the wall. A bold move. Now they are eye to eye. Grace kisses Costa for a long beat. Grace breaks the kiss. Holds a finger to her lips; shhh. She turns and exits. The door shuts behind her. Costa is going to miss Grace.

question: Jesus, he was a cop. He's dead because of you, because you made the choice. The choice to fuck with me. That, John, was a very bad choice. A T intersection ahead.
answer: Which way? Left, right?

question: Left. Costa makes the turn. It leads to a HIGHWAY. You're dead, John Costa. You fucked with the wrong man, shitsmear. Costa is shaking, looks in the rearview. Asher rips the rearview off the windshield. Faster, asshole.
answer: I'm flooring it.

question: Shut up. Faster. Costa pulls onto the highway, buckles his safety belt. Asher scoffs at the gesture, then does likewise. Give me your wallet. Give it over. Right now. Costa does. Asher looks through it, pockets it. Costa tries to focus on driving.
answer: Are you going to kill me?

question: You're goddamn right I am. I've been dreaming about it, John. Pass the truck, John. Before I blow your head off!
answer: God help me. Costa swings out to pass the truck.

question: There. Turn there. A hard-to-see side road. Costa JAMS the BRAKES to make the turn. Asher SLAPS him. Careful.
answer: Okay. Sorry. Sorry. You don't want to do this.

question: Yes I do. John, do you have any idea how many people I have killed? It's always been business. This time is personal.
answer: Please be cool. C'mon, we don't even know each other.

question: Shut up. Art Man. You are stupid or crazy or both. Will you drive faster? I'll shoot you in the thigh. Will that get your attention. Costa speeds up.
answer: Don't, man. I got money. You want money, I'll give you money. I got paintings. What do you want? Talk to me, Martin.

question: I am not Martin. There is no Martin.
answer: Of course. No Martin. What do you want? What's my life worth to you?

question: Nothing. And everything. This is deeper than money. Shut up. Talk is done. Talk is over. Understand that. You are over. Just shut the fuck up. Asher lights a cigarette. A sharp turn ahead. Costa speeding up.
answer: Okay, please, Martin. Martin. Be cool. Asher aims his pistol at Costa's head.

question: Which way's the river? Go to the river. The Cop makes a right.
answer: Rot in hell, Martin Asher.

question: Turn around. Let's go! Nothing broken?
answer: I think my hand is broken.

question: Don't move, okay. This hurt?
answer: God yes. Stop that.

question: You're going to the hospital. You'll be fine.
answer: Is he dead?

question: Please, Jean. I called your wife. I'm having someone take you home to her. There is nothing left to do here. Reynaud doesn't want to leave his dead comrade. I'm ordering you home. Reynaud acquiesces. A Uniform escorts him out of there. Director Gillet crosses to Grace, who was watching him. She sips coffee, an icepack on her ankle.
answer: You're really good with people. Gillet shrugs.

question: How's Mr. Costa?
answer: He got off light. With a broken wrist and fifty stitches. Lucky man.

question: My luck has run out. Until today I have never had to bury a friend. Grace squeezes his arm.
answer: I'm sorry, Director.

question: Thankfully it's over. We have our man. Asher's DNA matched the hairs recovered on Ford's body and in the apartment.
answer: Hey.

question: Hey.
answer: Hey. Ouch, Doc. That's not rawhide.

question: You okay?
answer: I'm okay. Thank you for rescuing me.

question: Anytime. Do you know where he was taking you?
answer: To my grave. He was going to kill me.

question: It's over. Let me take you out tonight. Let's have some fun. I owe you that.
answer: What's fun for you? You want to go to the shooting range or the morgue? Grace is hurt by that. I'm sorry.

question: It's going to take a couple days to depose you and get a full statement. I thought you might enjoy a break before you have to...
answer: I know a place. You drive. I'm happy to be alive but it's like this door has been opened. I don't think I was naive. But everything is different now.

question: You'll fold this experience into your life and be stronger for it.
answer: How do you deal with it? All the misery and pain and violence.

question: I can stop monsters, John. And because I can, I have to.
answer: So is it a calling or a curse?

question: Neither. It's just my job.
answer: When I was in med school I saw a guy on a Harley get T-boned by a Daihatsu. He was screaming in pain and needed help and I knew what to do, I had all my certs, but I saw all this blood and froze. I failed the big test. Bye-bye, med school. Hello, graphic design.

question: Roy Wilson.
answer: The man on the Harley. Costa REACTS. Sighs. So you knew about that. No wonder you knew what to say to keep me cooperating.

question: You're a sharp one, John Costa.
answer: You threw me in a tiger cage like a piece of meat.

question: That's right. You were the cheese in the trap. We stopped a monster. That's what matters. Grace is utterly unapologetic. It makes Costa like her even more. I'm sorry. I'm a pig.
answer: I don't trust anyone who's too organized. Grace puts some MUSIC ON the CLOCK RADIO.

question: Want a beer?
answer: Please. She grabs a couple cold ones from the mini-fridge. Which is it, are you a runner or chaser?

question: What's that mean?
answer: People like you --

question: People like me?
answer: Yeah, people like you. Hardcore. Gung-ho people like you. And you know what I mean. People like you are either runners or chasers. Grace looks at Costa.

question: You are a trip, John Costa. He's not letting her off the hook. She plays along. Okay. I guess I'm running and chasing. Costa REACTS.
answer: I'm sorry. I didn't know.

question: Growing up I quit speaking after that. I didn't say a word for three years. When you're not in the conversation, you get forgotten real quick. So I'd watch people. Study them. The mouth can say anything, but the body doesn't lie. The tilt of the head, the way the hands move. Grace draws closer. Costa watching her mouth.
answer: How'd you get your voice back?

question: The day my Uncle died. The truth exploded out of me like a vision. My Uncle and Father had been arguing, there was a gunshot and my father was dead.
answer: You are very intense, you know that?

question: I remember my Uncle telling me not to say anything. And I didn't. I made myself forget why. The day he died my voice and my memory came back. I screamed for an hour. Very primal. I haven't shut up since.
answer: Why did your Uncle do it?

question: Land. Great-grandpa owned half of Pennsylvania. My Uncle wanted control and sold it all. All that's left is an old farmhouse and a horse pasture. My father's murderer got away with it because I couldn't open my mouth.
answer: That's a hell of a lot of responsibility for you to put on the shoulders of an eight-year-old girl. Grace blinks, looks at Costa. That's exactly what she needed to hear.

question: Something good game out of it. The dead can't speak. Now I'm their voice. Costa cups her face and kisses her. Grace breaks away, a little hesitant. Something is bothering her. Martin Asher is dead, right? Costa REACTS.
answer: Can we please forget about him?

question: That's the point. He's dead, so there won't be a trial where you or I would have to admit under oath that we did anything inappropriate.
answer: We haven't done anything. That's about to change. Grace stands, pulls him off the couch. Begins undressing him. She finds horrible dog-bite scars.

question: Jesus.
answer: In college we tried to make my friend's German Shepherd take a bong hit.

question: How mean. Serves you right. Costa pulls Grace to her feet. Grace retreating. Step by step across the room. Costa. Pursuing. Slowly. Determined. The heat. The immediacy building. Costa grabs her. Pushing her. Up against the wall. The phone CLATTERS to the floor. Grace's eyes widen. Two mouths. Inches apart. Costa's hand reaches up her skirt. Exploring. Grace swallows. His hand reaching into her panties. Grace's eyes looking away. As she grabs his arm. Pulling. Pushing. Wanting. Her mouth. Avoiding his. Their breath mingling. Until. Costa's lips crush down on hers. The kiss devouring. Knocking pictures off the walls. Grace's hands pulling him closer. Costa picks her up. Throws her on the bed. He tears at her blouse. Her white lace bra. Grace's back arching. Her legs wrapping around him. As her eyes flutter open. Looking up at the ceiling, she gasps. Costa stops. Turns. To see what she's looking at. Surprised to see pictures of Asher's victims, the crime scenes. Staring down at them. Costa turns to Grace, whispers.
answer: Let them watch. Grace looking deep into Costa's eyes. Nods her head. Costa flips her onto her stomach...

question: John. John. Costa stirs.
answer: Mmmmm. Morning. He sees the blood. Doesn't really react. My stitches must have ripped. Grace hands him a towel. Presses it against his shoulder.

question: I thought you were scared of blood?
answer: You better take a shower.

question: Staple his mouth too, Doc. Grace's CELL RINGS. She exits to take the call. Vanderholt.
answer: Grace. I ran Mrs. Asher's DNA against the suspect down here. No way it's her son. A beat.

question: Not her son? You're sure?
answer: Lab ran the test twice.

question: That's weird. Was he adopted, switched at birth?
answer: Listen for a minute. There was a match. John Costa is Mrs. Asher's biological son. Grace laughs. It's a joke.

question: So John Costa is really Martin Asher?
answer: Dear God, I wish I was joking. Grace turns and REACTS.

question: Holy shit. Costa takes a step toward her. The street cop motions for Costa to stay back. Costa REACTS.
answer: She screwed it up, didn't she?

question: Who?
answer: I should have cut her throat when I saw her on the ferry. That's the least she deserves. Please don't do anything, Grace. It would hurt me so much if I had to hurt you.

question: Good idea. Don't hurt me. Costa shakes his head, his brow set with a grim determination. He turns, enters a stairwell and exits the building. Grace's heart is breaking. Shit! She kicks the wall and gives chase, runs into the stairwell. Police emergency. We need to pursue him. He's a murder suspect. The Cop cocks his head, looks at Grace like she's a nutcase. Grace dials her cell phone. Director Gillet, there's an emergency, can you please tell this officer to cooperate with me? Grace hands the cell phone to the Cop.
answer: Hello, Mother. Asher forces his way inside. Mrs. Asher SCREAMS.

question: No answer. She turns her phone off.
answer: What happened to Rex? He was a real dog, right, Mom? Rolls up his sleeve, revealing the dog bite scars.

question: I hope the son of a bitch doesn't shoot me with the gun you gave him. What else did you give Asher?
answer: Shut up and focus. That kind of shit helps no one right now. Get right, I got left. WHAM! Reynaud KICKS the door. Grace is first in. Don't move! It's Mrs. Asher. Sans head, sitting on the couch. Grace turns away, REACTS. She sees Mrs. Asher's head. Omigod. Reynaud enters. Sees Mrs. Asher's head.

question: He's gone. Reynaud looks at Grace. Grace feels hollow, miserable. My best friend died protecting a serial killer so you could get laid. Very nice. Grace REACTS. The cat is out of the bag.
answer: That's none of your business.

question: No? It's my case.
answer: Back off, Reynaud. Asher fooled you too.

question: At least I didn't fuck him. Grace walks off. Reynaud intercepts her.
answer: Touch me again and I will kick your ass.

question: They're on their way from the airport. Grace nods, chews a nail. Your old life is over. There is no going back.
answer: I know.

question: You're still young. Whatever happens, be strong. Where is he, Grace? How do we find him?
answer: Director, I'm the last person you should be discussing the case with at this point.

question: Grace. You know his mind, and his heart. Where is he? A beat.
answer: Not here. This city no longer has the psychic gravity to hold him here. Try Mexico, getting a facelift.

question: We ID'd the remains in the morgue. The real ID. He hands her a picture of the man whom we thought was Asher.
answer: Richard Hart.

question: He was an addict. And a thief. An art thief. He hits galleries in Europe and North America. Traveled back and forth smuggling and selling stolen canvasses.
answer: Let me guess, Costa was selling stolen art for Hart and never gave him the money. Now Hart is just another one of Asher's victims. Director Gillet.

question: Costa owed him eight thousand. Those are E-mails off Hart's computer.
answer: Go to hell. I won't pay you a dime. I'm not scared of you. Come and get me. I will never pay you, dumbass. Asher taunted Hart into a confrontation. Jesus. It was right there in my face. I was interpreting behavior from two different suspects.

question: He had us all fooled, Grace. All of us. If Asher can do that, what else can he do?
answer: Anything he wants. KNOCKING. Gillet stands, crosses, opens his door. Two FBI SUPERVISORS enter. Grim, silver-haired. Grace stands. Ah, the undertakers have arrived for my career.

question: Anything he wants. KNOCKING. Gillet stands, crosses, opens his door. Two FBI SUPERVISORS enter. Grim, silver-haired. Grace stands. Ah, the undertakers have arrived for my career.
answer: Have your rights been explained to you and has an indication to that effect been made in your employee record?

question: Yessir.
answer: Agent Vanderholt. Why would Asher kill Ford, if nobody knew he was Costa. If he wasn't going to use Ford's identity?

question: He needed a murder he could link not only Richard Hart to but also to his past victims. Hart's behavior was consistent with a disorganized drug addict following the rules of the criminal road by attempting to kill a debtor who won't pay. He had no idea he was being manipulated by a serial killer. Asher wasn't becoming disorganized and decomposing into madness, he was evolving. The Ford murder was staged and I missed it. Asher drove Ford's car there with Ford unconscious in the car. Ether maybe, GHB. Something that disappears. Asher works out, heads to the parking lot. Pulls Ford out of the trunk. And strangles him. He left a couple of Hart's hairs on the body. Asher leans over Todd Ford, strangling the unconscious man with the garotte. Asher places a couple of Hart's hairs on the body. He draws a nice portrait of Mr. Hart and he's now inside the heart of Montreal PD's investigation. Evidence at the Ford crime scene led to an apartment with more of Hart's DNA. And evidence linking Hart to Asher's crimes. Hart never set food in that apartment. Asher staged everything.
answer: Mr. Hart, not Asher, murdered the Montreal Inspector, correct?

question: Yes. Hart thought Costa was systematically destroying his life. Hart's violent explosion was inevitable.
answer: How could Asher plan on Hart snapping like that?

question: He couldn't. My guess is Asher intended to kill Hart and make it look like suicide. The authorities would find the body and close the Martin Asher file.
answer: This ethics panel has no choice but to recommend terminating you for misconduct. Do you wish to make a statement? Grace shakes her head Please speak up for the record. Grace leans into her mike.
